Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: South Pole Ice Core Chronology and Climate Records using Chemical and Microparticle Measurements
Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative project explores the signatures and causes of natural climate change in the region surrounding Antarctica over the last 40,000 years as the Earth transitioned from an ice age into the modern warm period. The researchers will investigate how the wind belts that surround Antarctica changed in their strength and position through time, and document explosive volcanic eruptions and CO2 cycling in the Southern Ocean as potential climate forcing mechanisms over this interval. Understanding how and why the climate varied naturally in the past is critical for improving understanding of modern climate change and projections of future climate under higher levels of atmospheric CO2.

The investigators plan to conduct a suite of chemical measurements along the 1500m length of the South Pole Ice Core, including major ion and trace element concentrations, and microparticle (dust) concentrations and size distributions. These measurements will (1) extend the South Pole record of explosive volcanic eruptions to 40,000 years using sulfate and particle data; (2) establish the relative timing of climate changes in dust source regions of Patagonia, New Zealand, and Australia using dust flux data; (3) investigate changes in the strength and position of the westerly wind belt using dust size distribution data; and (4) quantify the flux of bioavailable trace metals deposited as dust to the Southern Ocean over time. These chemistry records will also be critical for creating the timescale that will be used by all researchers studying records from the South Pole core. The project will support four graduate students and several undergraduate students across three different institutions, and become a focus of the investigators' efforts to disseminate outcomes of climate change science to the broader community.

I

Intellectual merit: Ice core records from Antarctica provide foundational information for understanding natural changes of the global climate and environment. The U.S. ice core science community collected a new 1751-meter South Pole Ice core (SPICEcore) in 2014-2016, with the goal to reconstruct a climate history from 54,300 years ago to present. A collaborative project between South Dakota State University, Dartmouth College and University of Maine performed high-resolution chemistry measurements along the entire length of the SPICEcore using specialized tools and state-of-the-art analytical equipment. The scientific objectives of the project were to improve our understanding of the volcanic, atmospheric circulation, and nutrient deposition history and how the history is related to climate variations during that time period. The objectives were accomplished with highly detailed chemical measurements that have produced (1) an accurate time scale for the SPICEcore and (2) chronological records of the chemical composition of the atmospheric environment. The chemical records are used to characterize the natural variations of the climate and other global environmental conditions over the 54,300 years covered by the ice core.

Broader impacts:  The outcomes of the collaborative project, presented in scientific publication and at scientific meetings, will improve future projections of Antarctic and Southern Hemisphere climate change and the response of the Antarctic ice sheet - a pressing societal concern as a potential major contributor to sea-level rise. This specific project focused on developing an accurate chronology for the SPICEcore from detailed chemical analysis and constructing a long record of explosive volcanic eruptions to evaluate the volcanic impact on climate variations during the last 54,300 years. The collaborative project also provided outstanding opportunities to educate the next generation of climate researchers at the undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral levels. At South Dakota State University, three graduate students and five undergraduate students were trained in chemical analysis of ice cores and contributed, by sampling and chemically analyzing the ice core and interpreting and publishing the chemical records, to achieving the objectives of this project. Project scientists (principal investigator and graduate students) also actively conducted outreach programs to middle schools in the South Dakota and western Minnesota region. Secondary education science teachers pursuing advanced degrees utilized the research at South Dakota State University to develop new chemistry curricula for highs schools in the region and beyond.
